userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials from Washington and Lee University Special Collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user assumes full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. Any materials used should be fully credited with the source. Permission for publication of this material, in part or in full, must be secured with the Head of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Preferred citation: [Identification of item], David Flavel Jamison Papers, WLU Coll. 0056, Special Collections, Leyburn Library, Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA.
In some cases the citation format may vary. Please contact Special Collections staff to verify the appropriate format.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Vanse W. Marshall in 1928.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes correspondence while Jamison was Secretary of War of South Carolina, 1861; scattered letters and papers pertaining to the South Carolina Secession Convention of which he was president, and papers related to his tenure as presiding judge of the military court of Gen. Beauregard's Corps, 1862-1864. Robert Woodward Barnwell and Lawrence Massillon Keitt are among the correspondents.

controlaccess.subject: Political science
Correspondence
Secession
controlaccess.geogname: United States -- Confederate States of America
controlaccess.subject: Military courts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 2 contains documents from early in the Confederacy during South Carolina's secession. Included in this folder are reports on Charleston Harbor defenses and plans for taking Fort Sumter. Along with plans for Fort Sumter, there are also early application letters from General Abraham Meyers and Mexican-American war veterans from the Palmetto Regiment. Also among these papers is the first report from Robert W. Barnwell (whose vote made Jefferson Davis president of the CSA) conferring with the National Government in Washington D.C.
